overview: From 2025-10-01 to 2025-11-01, elizaos/eliza had 61 new PRs (53 merged), 18 new issues, and 25 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Imports not found in index.ts with Eliza CLI 1.61
topIssues.author: matteo-brandolino
topIssues.body:
## Describe the bug
When creating a new project using `elizaos create`, some imports in `index.ts` fail:
Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'logger'.ts(2305) Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'IAgentRuntime'.ts(2305) Module '"@Elizaos/core"' has no exported member 'ProjectAgent'.ts(2305)
Copy code

## To Reproduce
1. Install Eliza CLI 1.61.  
2. Run `elizaos create` to generate a new project.  
3. Open `index.ts` and try to import `logger`, `IAgentRuntime`, or `ProjectAgent` from `@Elizaos/core`.  

## Expected behavior
These members should be correctly exported and importable from `@Elizaos/core` in a newly generated project.  

## Screenshots
<!-- Add screenshots if applicable -->

## Additional context
- Eliza CLI version: 1.61  
- This occurs immediately after project creation without any modifications.  
- Possible regression from previous versions of `@Elizaos/core`.

topIssues.title: The documentation for plugins isn't correct.
topIssues.author: ryanmstokes
topIssues.body: Seriously how are you even letting anyone use this right now? This is one of the worst documented frameworks I've ever seen despite having so much documentation. You can't even scaffold a plugin following your documentation without it throwing errors.

topIssues.title: `Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code'` after installing elizaOS CLI
topIssues.author: schmidsi
topIssues.body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm following the steps described here: https://docs.elizaos.ai/installation#cli-version-conflicts-mismatches

After running `elizaos --version`, I get an error message: `error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'`

**To Reproduce**

1. Install the CLI globally: `bun install -g @elizaos/cli`
2. Verify installation: `elizaos --version`
3. Observe the error: `error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'`

**Expected behavior**

The `elizaos --version` command should display the installed version number (e.g., `1.6.2`).

**Screenshots**
```
$ bun install -g @elizaos/cli
bun add v1.2.15 (df017990)
Saved lockfile

installed @elizaos/cli@1.6.2 with binaries:

elizaos

[53.00ms] done

$ elizaos --version
error: Cannot find module '@anthropic-ai/claude-code' from '/Users/schmidsi/.bun/install/global/node_modules/@elizaos/cli/dist/index.js'

Bun v1.2.15 (macOS arm64)
```

**Additional context**

- OS: macOS 15.6.1 (Build 24G90)
- Node version: v24.1.0
- Bun version: v1.3.1
- The `@anthropic-ai/claude-code` dependency appears to be missing from the package's transitive dependencies

topPRs.title: chore: merge develop into main
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
Merging latest changes from develop branch into main

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Introduces a pluggable message service and generateText API in core, unifies server startup/config, adds a Docker/ECS deploy command to the CLI, enables duplicate agent names via UUID-only identity, and improves memory pagination, plugin/character handling, and tests.
> 
> - **Core**:
>   - Adds pluggable `IMessageService` with `DefaultMessageService` and `shouldRespond` logic; centralizes message deletion/channel clear.
>   - Introduces `generateText()` API and refines model types/options.
>   - Adds character utilities (`buildCharacterPlugins`, parsing/validation/merge) and secrets/env loading helpers.
>   - Enhances DB `getMemories` with `offset` pagination.
>   - Extensive tests for runtime, prompts, UUID, character, message service.
> - **Server**:
>   - Unifies startup via `AgentServer.start(config)` (auto-init, port resolution, optional agents), removes plugin/config managers.
>   - Loader now ensures deterministic UUID from name; improves character env secret merging.
>   - Agent update endpoint restarts on plugin changes, in-place updates otherwise.
>   - Memory routes map `channelId`‚Üíagent `roomId`.
>   - Broad test updates (bootstrap autoload, CLI API, lifecycle, socket flow, CRUD UUID).
> - **CLI**:
>   - Adds `deploy` command (Docker build/push to AWS ECR, ECS deploy) with API/Docker utilities.
>   - Adds `tee eigen` wrapper; refactors `start/dev/test` to new server API; improves `create` flags and template resolution.
>   - Removes legacy module/port utilities; updates docs and dependencies.
> - **Plugins**:
>   - Bootstrap: routes message handling through runtime message service; removes legacy provider; improves embedding checks.
>   - SQL: drops unique constraint on agent name (UUID-only identity) and adds migration/tests; supports `offset` in memories.
> - **Client/Examples**:
>   - Adjusts entityId mapping for memories; adds `examples/generate-text.ts`.
> - **Misc**:
>   - Bumps versions to `1.6.2-alpha.26`; updates Renovate config and disables tests for types-only pkg.
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 0538c6551724caf8ad746d613ee5adaa06407d48. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

topPRs.title: feat: create @elizaos/react package with headless React hooks
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
## Overview This PR introduces a new **** package containing headless, reusable React hooks extracted from the client package. This enables external developers to build custom UIs for ElizaOS agents while maintaining full type safety and React Query integration. ## What's New ### Package: A standalone package providing headless React hooks with: - ‚úÖ Zero UI coupling (no toasts, navigation, or DOM dependencies) - ‚úÖ Full TypeScript support with proper type declarations - ‚úÖ TanStack React Query for caching and state management - ‚úÖ Network-aware polling that adapts to connection quality - ‚úÖ Composable lifecycle callbacks (onSuccess, onError, onMutate) ### Hooks Included (30 total) **Agents (8 hooks)** - `useAgents`, `useAgent`, `useStartAgent`, `useStopAgent` - `useAgentActions`, `useDeleteLog`, `useAgentPanels`, `useAgentsWithDetails` **Runs (2 hooks)** - `useAgentRuns`, `useAgentRunDetail` **Messaging (5 hooks)** - `useServers`, `useChannels`, `useChannelDetails`, `useChannelParticipants`, `useDeleteChannel` **Messages (3 hooks)** - `useChannelMessages` (stateful with pagination), `useDeleteChannelMessage`, `useClearChannelMessages` **Memories (6 hooks)** - `useAgentMemories`, `useDeleteMemory`, `useDeleteAllMemories`, `useUpdateMemory`, `useDeleteGroupMemory`, `useClearGroupChat` **Internal/Agent-Perspective (6 hooks)** - `useAgentInternalActions`, `useDeleteAgentInternalLog`, `useAgentInternalMemories` - `useDeleteAgentInternalMemory`, `useDeleteAllAgentInternalMemories`, `useUpdateAgentInternalMemory` ## Architecture ```tsx import { QueryClient, QueryClientProvider } from '@tanstack/react-query'; import { ElizaReactProvider, useAgents, useStartAgent } from '@elizaos/react'; const queryClient = new QueryClient(); function App() { return ( ); } function AgentList() { const { data: agents, isLoading } = useAgents(); const startAgent = useStartAgent({ onSuccess: () => toast.success('Agent started!'), }); if (isLoading) return
Loading...
; return (
{agents?.map((agent) => (

{agent.name}

))}
); } ``` ## Benefits 1. **Reusability**: External developers can build custom UIs using these hooks 2. **Type Safety**: Full TypeScript support with types from `@elizaos/api-client` 3. **Performance**: Smart polling adapts to network quality (2G ‚Üí 4G) 4. **Separation of Concerns**: UI logic stays in components, data logic in hooks 5. **Future-proof**: Ready for migration of `packages/client` to consume these hooks ## Testing - ‚úÖ Package builds successfully with TypeScript declarations - ‚úÖ All hooks properly typed with React Query v5 signatures - ‚úÖ Zero build errors or type issues - ‚úÖ Ready for integration into turbo build pipeline ## Next Steps (Future PRs) - Migrate `packages/client` to consume `@elizaos/react` - Add unit tests for hooks with mocked ElizaClient - Publish to npm for external consumption ## Files Changed - `packages/react/` - New package with provider, hooks, and documentation - Comprehensive README with installation, API reference, and examples --- **Ready for review!** üöÄ --- > [!NOTE] > Introduces a new `@elizaos/react` package with headless, type-safe React hooks and provider (plus build/docs), integrates it into the workspace, and publishes comprehensive core type declarations. > > - **New package `@elizaos/react`**: > - Headless React hooks and provider (`ElizaReactProvider`) built on `@tanstack/react-query` and `@elizaos/api-client`. > - Hooks for: agents, runs, messaging (servers/channels), messages (stateful + pagination), memories, and internal agent-perspective operations. > - Network-aware polling, composable mutation callbacks, TypeScript types, and index exports. > - Build tooling (`build.ts`, bunfig, tsconfigs), and comprehensive README. > - **Workspace integration**: > - Added to lockfile/workspace with peer/dev deps. > - **Type declarations**: > - Added/updated numerous `@elizaos/core` `.d.ts` and source maps to expose APIs/types for consumers. > > Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 5a290e0071637d785858567d960ab7d1d5e54456. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).

topPRs.title: feat(server): Jobs API for one-off agent messaging with middleware refactor
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
## Summary

This PR implements a **Jobs API** for one-off messaging functionality, enabling external systems to send single messages to agents and poll for responses without maintaining persistent sessions. This is ideal for stateless integrations similar to SDK patterns.

Additionally, this PR **refactors the middleware architecture** into a modular structure for better maintainability and reusability.

---

## üìä Scope

- **28 files changed**: +4,592 insertions, -409 deletions
- **Net addition**: ~4,183 lines (implementation, tests, docs, examples)

---

## üöÄ Core Features

### Jobs API Implementation
- **Server Router** (`packages/server/src/api/messaging/jobs.ts` - 681 lines)
  - `POST /api/messaging/jobs` - Create a new job (send message to agent)
  - `GET /api/messaging/jobs/:jobId` - Poll job status and retrieve result  
  - `GET /api/messaging/jobs` - List all jobs (admin/debugging)
  - `GET /api/messaging/jobs/health` - Health check endpoint

- **API Client Service** (`packages/api-client/src/services/jobs.ts` - 423 lines)
  - Full TypeScript client with type-safe methods
  - Integrated into `ElizaClient` as `client.jobs`
  - Built-in polling and retry logic

### Key Capabilities
‚úÖ **Automatic agent selection** - Uses first available agent if not specified  
‚úÖ **Configurable timeouts** - Default: 30s, Max: 5 minutes  
‚úÖ **In-memory job storage** - With automatic cleanup to prevent memory leaks  
‚úÖ **Job status tracking** - `pending ‚Üí processing ‚Üí completed/failed/timeout`  
‚úÖ **Metadata support** - Custom tracking fields  
‚úÖ **Intelligent message handling** - Filters intermediate action messages, waits for final result  
‚úÖ **Memory leak prevention** - Max 10k jobs with automatic cleanup  

### Message Flow
1. Client creates job via POST request
2. System creates temporary channel for job isolation
3. User message is sent to channel and emitted to internal message bus
4. Agent processes message via normal flow and responds
5. Response is captured and stored in job result (filters out "Executing action..." intermediate messages)
6. Client polls GET endpoint to retrieve result
7. Job auto-expires and cleans up after timeout

---

## üèóÔ∏è Middleware Refactor

Consolidated middleware from a single monolithic file into a modular structure:

**Before**: `packages/server/src/api/shared/middleware.ts` (331 lines - deleted)

**After**: `packages/server/src/middleware/` directory structure:
- `auth.ts` (40 lines) - Authentication middleware
- `rate-limit.ts` (141 lines) - Rate limiting with in-memory store
- `security.ts` (81 lines) - Security headers and CORS
- `validation.ts` (119 lines) - Request validation utilities
- `index.ts` (27 lines) - Barrel exports

**Total**: 408 lines across 5 focused modules

**Benefits**:
- Better separation of concerns
- Easier to test individual middleware
- More maintainable and extensible
- Clearer imports throughout the codebase

---

## üìò Type Definitions

**New types** (`packages/server/src/types/jobs.ts` - 171 lines, `packages/api-client/src/types/jobs.ts` - 167 lines):
```typescript
enum JobStatus {
  PENDING = 'pending',
  PROCESSING = 'processing', 
  COMPLETED = 'completed',
  FAILED = 'failed',
  TIMEOUT = 'timeout'
}

interface CreateJobRequest {
  agentId?: UUID;
  userId: UUID;
  content: string;
  metadata?: Record<string, unknown>;
  timeoutMs?: number;
}

interface JobResult {
  message: {
    content: string;
    processingTimeMs: number;
  };
}

interface JobDetailsResponse {
  jobId: string;
  status: JobStatus;
  result?: JobResult;
  error?: string;
  createdAt: number;
  expiresAt: number;
  metadata?: Record<string, unknown>;
}
```

---

## üß™ Test Coverage (1,523 lines)

### Server Unit Tests (`packages/server/src/api/messaging/__tests__/jobs.test.ts` - 589 lines)
- ‚úÖ Job creation (with/without agent ID)
- ‚úÖ Auto agent selection
- ‚úÖ Job status polling
- ‚úÖ Job listing and filtering
- ‚úÖ Health check endpoint
- ‚úÖ Timeout handling
- ‚úÖ Validation (missing fields, invalid UUIDs, timeout limits)
- ‚úÖ Error scenarios (agent not found, creation failures)
- ‚úÖ Cleanup mechanisms
- ‚úÖ Job expiration

### Server Integration Tests (`packages/server/src/__tests__/integration/jobs-message-flow.test.ts` - 335 lines)
- ‚úÖ End-to-end message bus integration
- ‚úÖ Real agent response capture
- ‚úÖ Message filtering (ignores "Executing action..." intermediate messages)
- ‚úÖ Timeout scenarios with message bus
- ‚úÖ Cleanup and listener removal

### API Client Tests (`packages/api-client/src/__tests__/services/jobs.test.ts` - 599 lines)
- ‚úÖ All JobsService methods
- ‚úÖ Request validation
- ‚úÖ Error handling
- ‚úÖ Response parsing
- ‚úÖ Client integration

### Middleware Tests
- ‚úÖ Auth middleware unit tests
- ‚úÖ Middleware composition tests

---

## üìö Documentation & Examples

### Comprehensive Guide (`docs/jobs-api-examples.md` - 475 lines)
**10 detailed usage examples**:
1. Minimal request (no agent ID)
2. With specific agent
3. With metadata and custom timeout
4. Shell script with polling
5. JavaScript/Node.js implementation
6. Python implementation
7. TypeScript with retry logic
8. Batch questions
9. Robust error handling
10. React Hook

**Languages covered**: Shell, JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, React

### Runnable Examples
- **SDK-Style Client** (`examples/jobs-api-example.ts` - 324 lines)
  - `JobsAPIClient` class with built-in polling
  - Multiple integration patterns
  - JWT authentication example
  - Error handling and retry logic

- **API Client Example** (`examples/jobs-api-client-example.ts` - 314 lines)
  - Uses official `@elizaos/api-client` 
  - Demonstrates `ElizaClient.jobs` service
  - Shows TypeScript best practices

---

## üîå API Usage Example

```bash
# Create a job
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/messaging/jobs \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "userId": "user-uuid",
    "content": "What is Bitcoin price?"
  }'

# Response
# {
#   "jobId": "abc123...",
#   "status": "processing",
#   "createdAt": 1234567890,
#   "expiresAt": 1234597890
# }

# Poll for result
curl http://localhost:3000/api/messaging/jobs/abc123...

# Response (when completed)
# {
#   "jobId": "abc123...",
#   "status": "completed",
#   "result": {
#     "message": {
#       "content": "Bitcoin is currently trading at...",
#       "processingTimeMs": 2341
#     }
#   }
# }
```

---

## üîß Technical Implementation Details

### Memory Management
- Jobs expire after configured timeout (default 30s, max 5 minutes)
- Cleanup runs every 60 seconds to remove completed/expired jobs
- Emergency cleanup at 10k jobs (removes oldest 10%)
- Message bus listeners auto-cleanup after timeout + 5s buffer
- Metrics tracking for job counts and cleanup operations

### Integration Points
- Integrated with existing messaging router
- Uses internal message bus for agent communication
- Creates temporary channels for job isolation
- Filters out intermediate "Executing action..." messages
- Captures only final agent responses

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Testing Notes

**Authentication temporarily disabled** for initial testing/development
- Need to re-enable `requireAuthOrApiKey` middleware before merging to production
- See TODO comments in `jobs.ts`

---

## üìã Next Steps

- [ ] Re-enable authentication middleware
- [ ] Consider database persistence (optional - currently in-memory is sufficient)
- [ ] Consider WebSocket notifications for real-time updates (optional enhancement)
- [ ] Add rate limiting per user/agent
- [ ] Add metrics/monitoring integration

---

## üîó Related

- Feature branch: `jobs-api`
- Implements one-off messaging pattern similar to external SDK integrations
- Part of broader effort to provide multiple client integration patterns (sessions, jobs, websockets)

---

## üéØ Key Files Summary

**Server Implementation:**
- `packages/server/src/api/messaging/jobs.ts` (681 lines) - Main API router
- `packages/server/src/types/jobs.ts` (171 lines) - Server-side types
- `packages/server/src/middleware/*` (408 lines) - Refactored middleware modules

**API Client:**
- `packages/api-client/src/services/jobs.ts` (423 lines) - Jobs service client
- `packages/api-client/src/types/jobs.ts` (167 lines) - Client-side types

**Tests:**
- Server unit: 589 lines
- Server integration: 335 lines  
- Client unit: 599 lines
- **Total test coverage: 1,523 lines**

**Documentation & Examples:**
- `docs/jobs-api-examples.md` (475 lines)
- `examples/jobs-api-example.ts` (324 lines)
- `examples/jobs-api-client-example.ts` (314 lines)
- **Total documentation: 1,113 lines**

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Adds a Jobs API with server endpoints and a client SDK (with polling/backoff), integrates it into messaging, introduces modular middleware, and includes types, docs, examples, and tests.
> 
> - **Backend (server)**:
>   - **Jobs API**: New router `api/messaging/jobs.ts` with `POST /jobs`, `GET /jobs/:jobId`, `GET /jobs`, `GET /jobs/health`; integrated into `messagingRouter`.
>   - Per-router in-memory jobs, timeouts/cleanup, metrics, API key auth, temporary channels, internal bus emission, and action-message filtering.
>   - Types added in `types/jobs.ts`; mounted and wired across server; security headers and minor route handling tweaks.
> - **Middleware**:
>   - Refactor to modular `middleware/` (`auth`, `rate-limit`, `security`, `validation`, `index`) and update imports across server; add/expand tests.
> - **API Client (@elizaos/api-client)**:
>   - New `JobsService` (`create`, `getJob`, `list`, `health`, `poll`, `createAndPoll`, `createAndPollWithBackoff`, `ask`) with types; exposed on `ElizaClient` and `index`.
>   - README updated with Jobs usage.
> - **Docs & Examples**:
>   - Add `docs/jobs-api-examples.md` and runnable examples `examples/jobs-api-*.ts`.
> - **Tests**:
>   - Add comprehensive server unit/integration tests for Jobs and middleware; add client `JobsService` tests.
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 1f9905a5ccdbc895286757935364f6ee53e83d85. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

topPRs.title: feat(server): Add x402 payment middleware to Jobs API
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
## Summary

This PR adds x402 payment middleware integration to the Jobs API, enabling cryptocurrency payments for AI agent access.

## Key Features

### Flexible Authentication Modes
- **Both API key + x402 enabled**: Requires BOTH `X-API-KEY` AND `X-PAYMENT` headers
- **Only API key** (x402=false): Requires only `X-API-KEY` header  
- **Only x402** (no API token): Requires only `X-PAYMENT` header
- **Neither enabled**: No authentication required

### Environment-Based Configuration
All settings via `.env` variables:
- `X402_ENABLED` - Enable/disable payment middleware
- `X402_WALLET_ADDRESS` - Receiving wallet address
- `X402_PRICE` - Price in USDC (default: $0.01)
- `X402_NETWORK` - Blockchain network (default: base-sepolia)
- `X402_USE_MAINNET` - Use CDP facilitator for production
- `CDP_API_KEY_ID`/`CDP_API_KEY_SECRET` - Required for mainnet

### Auto-Discovery
Endpoints automatically listed in x402 Bazaar (mainnet) with:
- Full JSON schemas (input/output)
- Descriptive documentation
- Pricing information

## Files Changed

### New Files
- `packages/server/src/middleware/x402.ts` - Main middleware implementation
- `packages/server/src/middleware/__tests__/x402.test.ts` - Comprehensive test suite (12 tests)
- `docs/x402-payment-integration.md` - Full documentation

### Modified Files  
- `packages/server/src/middleware/index.ts` - Export x402 middleware
- `packages/server/src/api/messaging/jobs.ts` - Integrated x402 on POST /jobs route
- `packages/server/package.json` - Added x402 dependencies
- `bun.lock` - Lockfile update

## Dependencies Added
- `x402-express@0.7.0` - Express middleware for x402 protocol
- `@coinbase/x402@0.7.0` - CDP facilitator for mainnet

## Testing

‚úÖ All 12 unit tests passing  
‚úÖ Build successful
‚úÖ No linter errors
‚úÖ TypeScript types validated

Run tests:
```bash
cd packages/server
bun test src/middleware/__tests__/x402.test.ts
```

## Documentation

See `docs/x402-payment-integration.md` for:
- Complete setup instructions
- Configuration examples
- Testing guide
- Security considerations
- Troubleshooting

## Breaking Changes

None - x402 is disabled by default and completely optional.

## References

- [x402 Protocol Docs](https://docs.cdp.coinbase.com/x402/)
- [x402 Quickstart for Sellers](https://docs.cdp.coinbase.com/x402/quickstart-for-sellers)
- [Coinbase Developer Platform](https://cdp.coinbase.com)

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Integrates x402 crypto payments into POST /api/messaging/jobs with env-configurable pricing/networks, adds docs/tests, and required dependencies.
> 
> - **Server/Middleware**:
>   - Add x402 payment middleware `createX402Middleware` and `x402LoggingMiddleware` in `packages/server/src/middleware/x402.ts`; export via `middleware/index.ts`.
>   - Supports dual auth: API key and/or x402 (`X-API-KEY`, `X-PAYMENT`) with env-based config (`X402_*`, `CDP_*`).
> - **API**:
>   - Protect `POST /api/messaging/jobs` using x402; includes route metadata (input/output schemas) for Bazaar discovery.
> - **Docs/Tests**:
>   - Add `docs/x402-payment-integration.md` with setup, modes, and examples.
>   - Add unit tests `packages/server/src/middleware/__tests__/x402.test.ts`.
> - **Dependencies**:
>   - Add `x402-express`, `@coinbase/x402`; update `packages/server/package.json`.
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit 57ae3cf5914a740335e67133ada19951df0125e5. This will update automatically on new commits. Configure [here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

topContributors.summary: standujar: Drove significant architectural improvements and feature development across the elizaOS ecosystem, merging 28 pull requests. Key contributions include a major refactor of the core config and plugin modules (elizaos/eliza#6037), the implementation of PostgreSQL Row-Level Security for multi-tenancy (elizaos/eliza#6101), and the creation of a unified messaging API (elizaos/eliza#6095). They also addressed critical bugs, such as fixing agent plugin reloading (elizaos/eliza#6040), and improved multiple plugins like `plugin-solana` and `plugin-discord`. This activity shows a primary focus on core feature development, large-scale refactoring, and addressing bugs across the platform.

0xbbjoker drove a significant architectural refactor across the ElizaOS ecosystem, aimed at modernizing core components and plugin interactions. His most impactful contributions involved migrating the entire system to UUID-only agent identification (elizaos/eliza#6036) and introducing a new `MessageService` interface (elizaos/eliza#6048), two massive undertakings that reshaped the platform's foundation. He extended this modernization effort by migrating multiple plugins like `plugin-discord` (#21) and `plugin-telegram` (#17) to a new message handling method, while also resolving critical issues like a plugin crash (elizaos-plugins/plugin-telegram#19). This work, combined with 12 code reviews, demonstrates a primary focus on large-scale refactoring, bug fixes, and feature implementation across the platform's core code and tests.

wtfsayo: Drove significant feature development across the Eliza OS ecosystem, merging 12 pull requests this month. Their most impactful contribution was the implementation of a new Jobs API for agent messaging in `elizaos/eliza#6098`, a substantial effort adding over 5,300 lines of code. Additionally, they integrated Streamdown and cross-platform crypto services (`elizaos/eliza#6082`) and added an Eigen TEE wrapper to the CLI (`elizaos/eliza#6065`). Based on their commits, their work was primarily focused on bug fixes and new feature development, with code changes also touching tests and refactoring.

odilitime: Drove significant feature development this month, primarily enhancing the Solana plugin by merging two large PRs for token upgrades and other improvements (elizaos-plugins/plugin-solana#14, #16). They also contributed to the core system by adding server port configuration support (elizaos/eliza#6038) and addressing two smaller bugs. In addition to their merged work, odilitime was an active collaborator, providing 7 code reviews, and has substantial work in progress with 7 open PRs across multiple plugins. This activity reflects a primary focus on new feature work and bug fixes, modifying mainly code and configuration files.

ChristopherTrimboli: Focused on significant refactoring and feature development within the `elizaos/eliza` repository, particularly around the command-line interface and deployment processes. He drove a major cleanup by removing over 5,400 lines of code related to Claude and plugin generation (elizaos/eliza#6087) while also introducing a new `login` command for the CLI (elizaos/eliza#6100). Christopher also landed a substantial change to deployment artifacts (+5256/-2909 lines in elizaos/eliza#6058) and supported the team by providing 4 code reviews. His contributions were primarily focused on other work (74%) and bug fixes.

madjin: This month, madjin drove significant feature development and operational improvements within the elizaos/elizaos.github.io repository. They implemented a major new MVP badge system for contributor achievements in PR #161, a substantial effort involving over 4,200 new lines of code. Madjin also enhanced system efficiency by adding adaptive rate limiting (PR #160) and improved the deployment process by creating a new guide (PR #158) and fixing a stats-copying bug (PR #157). Their contributions show a balanced focus across feature work, bug fixes, and documentation, primarily modifying code and configuration files.

yungalgo: Focused on improving the user experience and content within the `elizaos/docs` repository, merging five pull requests. Their most impactful work included adding a new 'launch resources' page (#76) which involved a significant content refactor, renaming the API Reference section for clarity (#75), and fixing broken plugin links (#74). This work, along with several comments on issues, demonstrates a clear focus on documentation improvements and bug fixes.

tcm390: This month, tcm390 focused on delivering a series of fixes and enhancements to the elizaos/eliza repository, merging five pull requests. Their most impactful contribution was elizaos/eliza#6045, which exposed the state cache and fixed bootstrap types. They also supported the team by approving two other pull requests, with their overall work consisting of 17 commits primarily focused on bug fixes and other code improvements.

lalalune: Made a substantial contribution to the `jeju` repository this month by adding new applications. They merged a single, large-scale pull request, `elizaos/jeju#1`, which introduced over 71k lines of code to accomplish this. In addition to this significant feature work, lalalune also planned future efforts by opening issues for new agents and load testing in the `jeju` repository (`#2`, `#3`, `#4`). Their work consisted of a mix of new feature development, refactoring, and tests.

tylermcwilliams: Focused on expanding core functionality by implementing the new `generateText()` API in the `elizaos/eliza` repository (PR #6062). This significant feature work involved adding nearly 400 lines of code and corresponding tests. In addition to this implementation, they engaged in discussions by commenting on four issues and one pull request. Their work was primarily centered on feature development, which accounted for two-thirds of their code changes.

5c0: Focused on a significant refactoring effort this month, opening a large pull request in elizaos/eliza (#6063). This single PR represents a substantial undertaking, modifying 111 files with over 5,500 new lines of code. Their activity shows a clear focus on code refactoring within the elizaos/eliza repository.

MonteCrypto999: Focused on adding new functionality to the Jupiter plugin this month. Their primary contribution was a significant pull request (elizaos-plugins/plugin-jupiter#3) to add referral fee support, which involved a substantial volume of changes (+5965/-431 lines across 31 files). This work encompassed new feature development, bugfixes, and documentation, with changes primarily affecting configuration files, code, and tests.

alex-nax: Focused on implementing a new feature to use a custom storage service, opening a significant pull request in elizaos/eliza (#6094). This single PR represents a substantial effort, modifying 418 files with over 35k line additions and 15k deletions. The code changes within this feature work were primarily a mix of tests, bugfixes, and other related development.

0xRabbidfly: Focused on bug fixes within the plugin ecosystem, submitting a fix for GIF animations not playing in Telegram (elizaos-plugins/plugin-telegram#20). This single bugfix PR involved a substantial effort, modifying 8 files with over 700 lines of new code and corresponding tests. They also identified and reported a related image rendering issue across two separate plugins (elizaos-plugins/plugin-knowledge#43, elizaos-plugins/plugin-telegram#18), demonstrating a focus on improving the user experience.

letmehateu: Focused on documentation maintenance within the elizaos/eliza repository this month. They contributed by fixing an old and broken link (PR #6047) and have another open pull request to address similar issues. All of their activity was concentrated on improving the project's documentation.
amlord: This month, amlord added the new 'nuggets' plugin to the elizaos-plugins/registry via PR #236, which consisted of a minor configuration file update.
github-advanced-security: Participated in code reviews this month, providing feedback via 5 review comments.

linear: Focused on product planning and defining new work this month, creating 11 issues in the elizaos/eliza repository. Their efforts were directed at scoping major initiatives, such as a unified messaging API (#6096) and cloud wireframes (#6019), as well as strategic analysis (#6018). They also tracked user-facing improvements, including a fix for markdown rendering (#5688), demonstrating a focus on product strategy and feature definition.

borisudovicic: Focused entirely on project planning and defining the future roadmap within the elizaos/eliza repository this month. They created 43 issues to structure upcoming work across a wide range of initiatives. This planning included defining a proof-of-concept for "Eigencloud" (#5768), outlining an "API Redesign" (#5917), and scoping efforts for "Testing & Reliability" (#5935) and "Core Documentation Expansion" (#5938).

matteo-brandolino: Focused on ecosystem engagement this month, identifying a bug and proposing a new integration. They reported an import issue with the Eliza CLI in elizaos/eliza#6031, which has since been closed, and actively participated in issue discussions. Additionally, they opened a pull request to add a new Moralis plugin to the registry (elizaos-plugins/registry#235).

icecoins: Focused on enhancing the Twitter plugin by opening a pull request to enable media uploads via the Twitter API v2 (elizaos-plugins/plugin-twitter#45). This contribution represents their sole activity for the month.

schmidsi: Focused on issue reporting this month, identifying and documenting a potential installation problem in the `elizaos/eliza` repository (#6088). They participated in the discussion on the issue, which was subsequently closed. Their activity was centered on the `elizaos/eliza` project.
douglasg14b: This month, douglasg14b focused on improving documentation quality by identifying and reporting an issue with broken plugin links (elizaos/eliza#6061).

ryanmstokes: This month, ryanmstokes focused on improving documentation quality within the elizaos/eliza repository. They identified and reported an issue regarding incorrect plugin documentation (#6070) and participated in issue discussions with two comments.
kempsterrrr: Contributed to the `elizaos/eliza` project by opening issue #6074 to suggest adding a gitignore file to the project creation process.

FellowTraveler: This month, their activity was centered on the `elizaos/eliza` repository, where they identified a potential configuration issue. They created and subsequently closed issue #6051, which raised a concern about the default port selection.
n1n-api: This month, n1n-api proposed a new integration by creating issue #6064 in the elizaos/eliza repository to add the n1n.ai API as a model provider.

Vianvolaeus: This month, Vianvolaeus's contribution was focused on product quality assurance. They identified and reported a potential bug in the user-facing weekly summary, noting an incorrect week and date display in issue elizaos/elizaos.github.io#168.

TensorNull: This month, TensorNull's contribution was focused on proposing new functionality for the ElizaOS project. They opened a feature request (elizaos/eliza#6055) to add support for the CometAPI. This was their sole contribution for the period.
